habitat_description:
Scarce literature exists on the habitat preferences of Spermophilus townsendii. Given this fact, along with the species’ recent reclassification, knowledge of its habitat is inferred from research on its former conspecifics S. mollis and S. canus.

S. townsendii inhabits shrub-steppe in the Columbia Basin. Plant associations within which the species is commonly found include: sagebrush and wheatgrass (Hedlund and Rickard, 1981); big sagebrush, shadscale, and winterfat (Groves and Steenhof, 1988; Yensen et al., 1992; Sharpe and Van Horne, 1998; Van Horne et al., 1998); sagebrush and bluegrass (Smith and Johnson, 1985); winterfat and cheatgrass (Smith and Johnson, 1985); winterfat and bluegrass (Smith and Johnson, 1985; Yensen et al., 1992); winterfat, big sagebrush, hop sage, Russian thistle, and cheatgrass (Smith and Johnson, 1985); winterfat and sagebrush (Van Horne et al., 1998). Reports of the species’ response to fire are mixed; however, generally, Townsend’s ground squirrels will inhabit recently burned shrubland (Hedlund and Rickard, 1981; Smith and Johnson, 1985; Groves and Steenhof, 1988).

Townsend’s ground squirrels are not found on grazed land (Medin and Clary, 1989). Their use of pure grasslands is not well-documented, as observations in the absence of shrubs are limited to recently burned shrublands (Groves and Steenhof, 1988; Smith and Johnson, 1998).
